newsitem.title: COLOMBIA: Justice minister says Colombia to okay extradition.
newsitem.headline: Justice minister says Colombia to okay extradition.

text.p: Colombia has no interest in harbouring drug lords and will move to lift a constitutional ban on extradition in effect since 1991, Justice Minister Carlos Medellin said on Tuesday.
"Drug traffickers will not take refuge in Colombia," Medellin said in a speech at Bogota's Modelo prison.

"They have tarnished the name of honest people who have fallen in this fight," he added, referring to the thousands of Colombians who have died fighting Colombia's U.S.-backed drug war over the past decade.

"Countries have the right to demand (control over) people who have committed crimes in their territory, that's called extradition," Medellin said, adding that it would be welcome as part of a series of measures aimed at strengthening Colombia's judicial system.

In subsequent remarks to reporters, Medellin added that the government would only move to lift Colombia's constitutional ban on extradition once Congress approved legislation submitted in mid-July that would stiffen prison sentences for drug trafficking and permit the confiscation of drug baron's property.
It was not clear how soon the legislation might win passage, but President Ernesto Samper asked lawmakers last week to give the measures top priority.

In a speech to the U.N. General Assembly in New York Monday, Samper proposed the creation of a world court for the handling of drug-related crimes and terrorism and said Colombia would back extradition as part of an international agreement on judicial cooperation.
He fell short of saying that the Colombia would approve extradition without such an agreement, but suggested that it would in subsequent remarks to Colombian television.

The 1991 ban was passed after hundreds of people -- including three presidential candidates, a justice minister, high court judges, journalists and scores of police officers -- were killed in a campaign of assassinations and bombings that drug lords waged against extradition in the late 1980s and early 1990s.
Colombia, the world's leading exporter of cocaine and a top supplier of heroin to the United States, is under heavy U.S. pressure to step up its war with drug mobs.

Samper, whose 1994 election campaign allegedly received millions of dollars in financing from the Cali cartel, has insisted repeatedly that Colombians are more victims of the drug trade than its villians.
